verses.text: In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam, Abijah became king over Judah.
verses.comment: Verse establishes the year Abijah begins ruling; aligns with parallel in 1 Kings.

verses.text: He reigned for three years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Micaiah, the daughter of Uriel of Gibeah. There was war between Abijah and Jeroboam.
verses.comment: Name rendered as 'Micaiah'; some texts read 'Maacah'.

verses.text: Abijah went out to battle with an army of valiant warriors, four hundred thousand chosen men. Jeroboam drew up in battle formation against him with eight hundred thousand chosen men, mighty men of valor.
verses.comment: Numbers maintained as in Hebrew text; rhetorical emphasis on size.

verses.text: Then Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim, in the hill country of Ephraim, and said, "Listen to me, Jeroboam and all Israel!
verses.comment: Direct address rendered for clarity; location specified.

verses.text: Do you not know that the LORD, the God of Israel, gave the kingship over Israel to David and his descendants forever by a covenant of salt?
verses.comment: "Covenant of salt" kept as idiom; expression refers to permanence.

verses.text: Yet Jeroboam son of Nebat, servant of Solomon son of David, rose up and rebelled against his master.
verses.comment: "Servant" here refers to official position, not household servant.

verses.text: Worthless men, scoundrels, gathered around him and defied Rehoboam son of Solomon when Rehoboam was young and inexperienced and could not withstand them.
verses.comment: Phrase "worthless men" reflects Hebrew 'sons of Belial'.

verses.text: So now you think to resist the kingdom of the LORD, which is in the hands of the descendants of David. You are a great multitude, and you have with you the golden calves that Jeroboam made for you as gods.
verses.comment: "Made for you as gods" clarifies their idolatrous purpose.

verses.text: Have you not driven out the priests of the LORD, the sons of Aaron, and the Levites, and made yourselves priests like the peoples of other lands? Whoever comes to consecrate himself with a young bull and seven rams becomes a priest to what are not gods.
verses.comment: "Priests to what are not gods" makes explicit the false worship.

verses.text: But as for us, the LORD is our God, and we have not forsaken Him. The priests who serve the LORD are sons of Aaron, and the Levites attend to their duties.
verses.comment: Maintains distinction between Aaronic and Levitical roles.

verses.text: Every morning and every evening they burn offerings to the LORD and fragrant incense. They arrange the bread on the pure table and attend to the golden lampstand so its lamps burn every evening. For we keep the charge of the LORD our God, but you have forsaken Him.
verses.comment: Respects various priestly rituals; phrase order made clear for modern readers.

verses.text: See, God is with us, leading us, with His priests who blow the trumpets to sound the battle alarm against you. People of Israel, do not fight against the LORD, the God of your ancestors, for you will not succeed.
verses.comment: Trumpets described as 'sounding the battle alarm' for clarity.

verses.text: But Jeroboam had sent an ambush to come from behind them; so his army was in front of Judah, and the ambush was behind them.
verses.comment: Tactical setup clarified for readability.

verses.text: When Judah turned, they saw that the battle was in front and behind them. So they cried out to the LORD, and the priests blew the trumpets.
verses.comment: Turns a poetic Hebrew construction into a direct sequence for clarity.

verses.text: Then the men of Judah shouted, and as they shouted, God struck down Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah.
verses.comment: God's intervention is emphasized as the decisive factor.

verses.text: The sons of Israel fled before Judah, and God gave them into their hands.
verses.comment: Concise summarization in line with Hebrew style.

verses.text: Abijah and his people struck them with a great slaughter, and five hundred thousand chosen men of Israel fell slain.
verses.comment: Large casualty number retained as in original, possibly idiomatic for 'very many.'

verses.text: Thus the sons of Israel were subdued at that time, and the sons of Judah prevailed because they relied on the LORD, the God of their fathers.
verses.comment: Causal reason—'because they relied on the LORD'—is emphasized.

verses.text: Abijah pursued Jeroboam and took from him the cities of Bethel and its villages, Jeshanah and its villages, and Ephron with its villages.
verses.comment: Cities listed in accordance with Hebrew order.

verses.text: Jeroboam did not recover strength again in the days of Abijah. The LORD struck him, and he died.
verses.comment: Shorter statement in Hebrew reflected in English.

verses.text: But Abijah became strong. He took fourteen wives, and fathered twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters.
verses.comment: Retained the numbers for children and wives per the text.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Abijah, his ways and his words, are written in the commentary of the prophet Iddo.
verses.comment: "Commentary" rendered for 'midrash'; reflects traditional meaning as an interpretive record.
